Physiological/Pathological: Both – normal endothelium under flow or diseased states (thrombosis, inflammation)
Cell Source: Primary human endothelial cells (e.g. HUVEC) or microvascular endothelial lines
Multiple Cell Types: Often single endothelium + transient blood cells in flow; can add fibroblasts or pericytes in advanced setups
Stromal Cells: No by default; user can co-culture stromal cells if chip design allows
Tissue-resident Immune: No; some resident immune cells in endothelium are minimal. Typically rely on added immune cells in flow
Circulating Immune: Yes (flowing leukocytes, platelets, etc. for adhesion assays)
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Not in a single chip, can link to other chips if user arranges
Extracellular Matrix: Yes (coating on channel surface, e.g. collagen/fibronectin)
3D Scaffold: No (2D monolayer in a microchannel; channel geometry is 3D)
Notable Features: Precision shear stress control, real-time imaging of cell adhesion/rolling/thrombosis under flow
Plate/Format (Throughput): Biochips with ~8 parallel channels; moderate throughput. Multiple chips can run in parallel
Max Culture Duration: Typically hours–days under flow; can extend up to ~1 week with careful perfusion
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes (microscopic observation of rolling, adhesion, fluorescence labeling)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes (effluent from chip can be collected)
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible via enzymatic detachment or flush-out
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix chip and stain endothelium in situ
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes; typically use permeability or molecular assays
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No, external flow sensors or imaging used
Perfused: Yes, continuous flow with Cellix pump
Gas Mix Controlled: By incubator only; chips often in enclosed system
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate, compound addition on the fly, no built-in automation besides pump programming
model_availability: Product (user assembles biology on Cellix hardware)

Model: Barrier/Epithelial Organ-on-Chip (e.g. Gut or Lung Interface)
Organs/Tissues: Epithelial layer (intestinal, alveolar) + endothelial channel on separate sides of a porous membrane
Physiological/Pathological: Both – healthy barrier or inflamed/infected states
Cell Source: Epithelial cells (Caco-2 for gut, A549 for lung, or primary) + endothelial cells below membrane
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, typically epithelium + endothelium. Stromal/immune optional if chip design permits
Stromal Cells: Optional (fibroblasts in matrix or separate compartment)
Tissue-resident Immune: Not by default; can add immune cells (macrophages, etc.) to epithelium or stroma
Circulating Immune: Yes if introduced into the endothelial (vascular) channel under flow
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Epithelium–endothelium crosstalk. Could chain chips for multi-organ if user designs it
Air-Liquid Interface: Yes for lung (ALI on epithelial side); gut usually fluid–fluid but possible variations
Extracellular Matrix: Yes (coating or hydrogel on membrane). Membrane is often synthetic but ECM-coated
3D Scaffold: Membrane + optional 3D gel region; partially 3D arrangement of cells on membrane
Notable Features: Flow in endothelium channel, parallel epithelial chamber (static or also perfused). Allows drug transport, immune cell migration
Plate/Format (Throughput): Standalone microfluidic chip (~4 compartments); moderate–low throughput
Max Culture Duration: ~1–2+ weeks possible if cells remain viable; typically up to 7–14 days
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes (translucent chip for confocal/fluorescence from top/bottom)
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible but more complex (trypsinize each side), can do end-point histology
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix + immunostain cross-sections or do 3D imaging of membrane layers
Readouts - TEER: Not by default unless user adds electrodes. Permeability/dye leakage typically used
Dead Volume: Low in microchannels, adjustable by reservoir/tubing
Perfused: Yes, typically the endothelial channel is under flow; epithelial side can be static or also perfused
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator-based, or ALI for lung epithelium. No separate on-chip regulation
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate changes, dosing in medium, no mechanical stretch by default
model_availability: Product (chips + Cellix pump; user configures cell types)
